title: Psalms Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 7.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms Chapter 7 according to the text?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: The chapter begins with 'Shiggaion of David,' indicating David as the author (Psalms 7:1).

questions.question: To whom is David singing in Psalms 7:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: David sang unto the LORD as mentioned in Psalms 7:1.

questions.question: What does David ask God to save him from in Psalms 7:1?
questions.correctAnswer: All them that persecute me
questions.explanation: David prays to be saved from all those who persecute him (Psalms 7:1).

questions.question: According to Psalms 7:2, David compares his soul to what animal being torn?
questions.correctAnswer: A lion
questions.explanation: David says lest he tear my soul like a lion, rending it in pieces (Psalms 7:2).

questions.question: What does David say he will do if he has done iniquity in his hands in Psalms 7:3?
options: He asks God to judge him
questions.correctAnswer: He asks God to judge him
questions.explanation: David calls on God to judge him if there is iniquity in his hands (Psalms 7:3).

questions.question: Who is Cush, mentioned in Psalms 7:1?
questions.correctAnswer: A Benjamite
questions.explanation: The chapter is concerning the words of Cush the Benjamite (Psalms 7:1).

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 7:5, David asks that his honour be laid in the dust.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David says, 'let him tread down my life upon the earth, and lay mine honour in the dust' (Psalms 7:5).

questions.question: What does David request God to do in Psalms 7:6?
options: Arise in anger and judge his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Arise in anger and judge his enemies
questions.explanation: David asks God to arise in anger and awake for the judgment He commanded (Psalms 7:6).

questions.question: According to Psalms 7:8, how does David want the LORD to judge him?
options: According to his righteousness and integrity
questions.correctAnswer: According to his righteousness and integrity
questions.explanation: David asks to be judged according to his righteousness and integrity (Psalms 7:8).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 7:10 says God saves those who are upright in heart.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse states that God saveth the upright in heart (Psalms 7:10).

questions.question: What does God do every day according to Psalms 7:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Is angry with the wicked
questions.explanation: God is angry with the wicked every day as stated in Psalms 7:11.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 7:17: 'I will praise the LORD according to his ______:'
questions.correctAnswer: righteousness
questions.explanation: The verse says 'I will praise the LORD according to his righteousness' (Psalms 7:17).

questions.question: What does the wicked man do according to Psalms 7:14?
options: Travails with iniquity and brings forth falsehood
questions.correctAnswer: Travails with iniquity and brings forth falsehood
questions.explanation: The wicked man is described as conceiving mischief and bringing forth falsehood (Psalms 7:14).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 7:15 says the wicked man falls into the pit he made.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse says 'He made a pit, and digged it, and is fallen into the ditch which he made' (Psalms 7:15).

questions.question: According to Psalms 7:13, what has God prepared for the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Instruments of death and arrows
questions.explanation: God has prepared instruments of death and ordained arrows against the persecutors (Psalms 7:13).

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 7, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in times of persecution?
options: Put your trust in the LORD, who saves from all persecutors
Rely on your own strength to overcome enemies
Avoid praying for deliverance to build patience
Ignore the persecution as a test of fate
questions.correctAnswer: Put your trust in the LORD, who saves from all persecutors
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:1 encourages putting trust in God and asking Him to save and deliver from persecutors. This shows the practical application of faith and dependence on God during trials (Psalms 7:1, 7:10, 7:11).

questions.question: How does Psalms 7 teach about integrity and honesty when accused unjustly?
options: Confess any wrongdoing and ask for forgiveness if innocent
Declare your innocence and ask God to judge your righteousness
Ignore accusations and retaliate against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Declare your innocence and ask God to judge your righteousness
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to judge him according to his righteousness and integrity (Psalms 7:3, 7:8). This teaches believers to maintain honesty and integrity before God and others.

questions.question: What does Psalms 7 teach about prayer and asking God for justice in the face of enemies?
options: Pray for God to arise in anger and execute righteous judgment
Seek revenge personally without involving God
Pray for patience but not for justice
Ignore the enemies and avoid praying about them
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for God to arise in anger and execute righteous judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:6 shows the psalmist asking God to arise in anger against enemies and to bring judgment as commanded, emphasizing prayer for divine justice.

questions.question: According to Psalms 7, how should we respond when others wrongfully become our enemies?
options: Continue to treat them peacefully and seek reconciliation
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to treat them peacefully and seek reconciliation
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states the psalmist has delivered him who was without cause his enemy, showing a heart of peace and forgiveness even when wronged.

questions.question: How does Psalms 7 instruct believers to view God’s judgment on the wicked?
options: God daily is angry with the wicked and will bring their mischief back upon them
God ignores the wicked and allows evil to prevail
God punishes the wicked only after long delays
God encourages people to take justice into their own hands
questions.correctAnswer: God daily is angry with the wicked and will bring their mischief back upon them
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:11 and 7:16 explain God’s continual anger with the wicked and how their evil returns upon their own heads.

questions.question: A believer struggles with bitterness towards an enemy. What biblical principle from Psalms 7 would encourage them toward humility and trust?
options: Trust God to defend the upright and leave judgment to Him
Plot secret revenge to satisfy personal anger
Hold onto bitterness as a sign of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to defend the upright and leave judgment to Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:10 shows that God is the defense of the upright in heart, encouraging believers to trust God rather than act out of bitterness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 7 teach about the consequences of deceit and wickedness?
options: The wicked who conceive mischief fall into the traps they set
Deceitful plans always succeed without consequence
Wickedness is rewarded in the end
The righteous are punished alongside the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked who conceive mischief fall into the traps they set
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 15 describe how the wicked bring forth falsehood and fall into the pit they dig, illustrating consequences of deceit.

questions.question: What does Psalms 7 reveal about the importance of praising God in response to His righteousness?
options: Praise God according to His righteousness and exalt His name
Only praise God when receiving blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Praise God according to His righteousness and exalt His name
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:17 emphasizes praising the LORD according to His righteousness and singing praise to His name, encouraging gratitude and worship.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 7, God only judges people once and then forgets their deeds.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:11 states that God is angry with the wicked every day, indicating ongoing judgment and awareness of deeds.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 7 teaches that God tests the hearts and reins of people to establish the just.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:9 states that God tries the hearts and reins, establishing the just and ending wickedness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "My defense is of God, which saveth the _____ in heart."
questions.correctAnswer: upright
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:10 declares that God's defense saves those who are upright in heart, emphasizing integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 7 illustrate the value of humility when facing false accusations?
options: By accepting God's judgment and not retaliating
By boasting about one's innocence to others
By refusing to acknowledge any fault
questions.correctAnswer: By accepting God's judgment and not retaliating
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls on God to judge him according to his righteousness and integrity, showing humility and reliance on divine justice rather than personal retaliation (Psalms 7:8, 7:6).

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance through trials can be drawn from Psalms 7?
options: Continue to trust God and praise Him despite enemies and trials
Give up praying when trials persist
Avoid fellowship with others during hardship
Take justice into your own hands
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to trust God and praise Him despite enemies and trials
questions.explanation: The psalmist prays for deliverance but ends with praise to God’s righteousness (Psalms 7:1, 7:17), showing perseverance through faith and worship.

questions.question: In terms of church life and fellowship, what does Psalms 7:7 suggest about the role of the congregation?
options: The congregation surrounds God in worship and encourages Him to act
The congregation should ignore the struggles of individuals
Each person should face trials alone without support
The congregation should judge individuals harshly
questions.correctAnswer: The congregation surrounds God in worship and encourages Him to act
questions.explanation: Verse 7 shows the congregation compassing God about, implying corporate worship and intercession for those in need.

questions.question: How does Psalms 7 guide us in dealing with temptation to respond to enemies with evil?
options: Trust God to judge righteously rather than repay evil
Return evil for evil to maintain honor
Ignore prayer and seek human support only
Conceal your feelings and pretend all is well
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to judge righteously rather than repay evil
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to judge him according to his righteousness and integrity, not repay evil, showing trust in God’s justice instead of personal retaliation (Psalms 7:3-5, 7:8).

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 7.

questions.question: In Psalms 7:1, David sings a Shiggaion to the LORD concerning the words of which individual?
questions.correctAnswer: Cush the Benjamite
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:1 explicitly states that David sang a Shiggaion concerning the words of Cush the Benjamite.

questions.question: The literary device used in Psalms 7:2, describing the soul being torn like a lion, is an example of:
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The phrase 'like a lion' in Psalms 7:2 is a simile, comparing the tearing of the soul to a lion’s attack.

questions.question: Psalms 7:3-5 presents a pattern of what literary form often seen in Hebrew poetry?
questions.correctAnswer: Confession and appeal
questions.explanation: In verses 3-5, David confesses possible iniquity and appeals for judgment and deliverance, a common form in Hebrew lament psalms.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Near Eastern justice, what does David request the LORD to do in Psalms 7:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Arise in anger and judge
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:6 calls upon the LORD to arise in anger because of David’s enemies and execute the divinely commanded judgment, reflecting ancient Near Eastern divine justice ideals.

questions.question: The phrase ‘So shall the congregation of the people compass thee about’ in Psalms 7:7 suggests what about the community's role?
options: The people surround God in worship
questions.correctAnswer: The people surround God in worship
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:7 implies the community gathers around the LORD, likely in worship or support, emphasizing collective acknowledgment of divine authority.

questions.question: In Psalms 7:8, David asks the LORD to judge him according to what criteria?
questions.correctAnswer: His righteousness and integrity
questions.explanation: David requests judgment based on his personal righteousness and integrity as stated in Psalms 7:8.

questions.question: The theological theme in Psalms 7:9, where God tries hearts and reins, is most closely connected to which Old Testament concept?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine omniscience and judgment
questions.explanation: The reference to God trying hearts and reins in Psalms 7:9 underscores God's all-knowing nature and his righteous judgment, a key theological theme in the Old Testament.

questions.question: Psalms 7:10 states, 'My defence is of God, which saveth the upright in heart.' This reflects which typology in biblical theology?
options: God as protector of the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God as protector of the righteous
questions.explanation: This verse typifies the biblical theme of God as the defender and savior of those who are upright in heart, consistent throughout Scripture.

questions.question: According to Psalms 7:11, how does God regard the wicked daily?
options: God is angry with the wicked every day
God is indifferent to the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: God is angry with the wicked every day
questions.explanation: Psalms 7:11 explicitly says God is angry with the wicked every day, highlighting God's ongoing opposition to wickedness.

questions.question: The imagery of God whetting his sword and bending his bow in Psalms 7:12-13 is best understood as a foreshadowing of:
options: The rise of a human king
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment against the wicked
questions.explanation: The preparation of weapons in these verses symbolizes God's readiness to execute judgment on the wicked.

questions.question: In Psalms 7:14-15, the person who conceives mischief and digs a pit but falls into it himself is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: The wicked person’s plan backfiring on himself is an example of situational irony.

questions.question: The phrase 'His mischief shall return upon his own head' in Psalms 7:16 reflects what principle seen throughout Scripture?
questions.correctAnswer: The principle of retributive justice
questions.explanation: This verse illustrates the biblical principle that evildoers suffer consequences of their own actions.

questions.question: The concluding verse, Psalms 7:17, expresses which of the following theological intentions?
options: To praise the LORD for His righteousness
To command the people to fast
questions.correctAnswer: To praise the LORD for His righteousness
questions.explanation: The psalm concludes with a vow to praise God according to His righteousness, emphasizing worship and trust.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 7 contains an explicit request for human judges to intervene in David’s situation.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David appeals to the LORD for judgment, not to human judges, as shown in Psalms 7:6-8.

questions.question: The phrase 'the righteous God trieth the hearts and reins' in Psalms 7:9 refers to the Hebrew concept of 'reins' as:
questions.correctAnswer: The innermost thoughts and feelings
questions.explanation: In Hebrew thought, 'reins' symbolize the seat of emotions and conscience, indicating God's examination of inner character.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason David pleads with the LORD in Psalms 7:1?
questions.correctAnswer: To be saved from persecutors
questions.explanation: David explicitly asks God to save him from all who persecute him, showing his trust in God's deliverance (Psalms 7:1). This matches the biblical theme of God as refuge (Psalm 46:1), deliverer (Psalm 34:17), and protector in times of trouble (2 Timothy 4:18).

questions.question: In Psalms 7:3, David challenges God to judge him if what condition is true?
options: If he has stolen from the poor
If he has done iniquity in his hands
If he has lied to the congregation
questions.correctAnswer: If he has done iniquity in his hands
questions.explanation: David invites God’s righteous judgment if there is any iniquity in his hands, emphasizing personal integrity before God (Psalms 7:3). This reflects the biblical principle of God’s holiness and justice (Psalm 51:4, Proverbs 16:2, Romans 2:6-8, 1 Peter 1:17).

questions.question: According to Psalms 7:5, what is David willing to endure if he is found guilty of wrongdoing?
options: To be banished from the land
To have his life taken and honor laid in the dust
To be forgotten by his people
questions.correctAnswer: To have his life taken and honor laid in the dust
questions.explanation: David expresses willingness that if he is guilty, his enemies may persecute his soul, take his life, and lay his honor in the dust (Psalms 7:5). This shows the seriousness of divine justice and the concept of bearing consequences for sin (Numbers 35:33, Ezekiel 18:20, Hebrews 10:30-31, Romans 6:23).

questions.question: What does David ask God to do in response to the rage of his enemies in Psalms 7:6?
options: To give David victory in battle
questions.correctAnswer: To arise and execute judgment
questions.explanation: David calls on God to arise in anger and awake to judge according to His command, revealing God’s role as righteous judge (Psalms 7:6). This aligns with biblical affirmations of God’s judicial authority (Psalm 9:7-8, Isaiah 66:15-16, Romans 14:10, Revelation 20:11-12).

questions.question: What does Psalms 7:8 reveal about the basis on which David desires to be judged by God?
options: According to his righteousness and integrity
questions.correctAnswer: According to his righteousness and integrity
questions.explanation: David asks God to judge him according to his righteousness and integrity, emphasizing moral uprightness as the basis for judgment (Psalms 7:8). This corresponds with broader biblical teaching on judgment according to deeds and heart condition (Ecclesiastes 12:14, 1 Samuel 16:7, 2 Corinthians 5:10, James 2:12).

questions.question: What does the Psalm say about God's testing of hearts and reins in Psalms 7:9?
options: God ignores the heart and focuses on actions
God tries the hearts and reins and establishes the just
questions.correctAnswer: God tries the hearts and reins and establishes the just
questions.explanation: The verse declares that God tests the hearts and reins (inner thoughts and motives) and establishes the just, highlighting God’s omniscient judgment (Psalms 7:9). This is consistent with scriptures emphasizing God’s knowledge of the heart (1 Chronicles 28:9, Jeremiah 17:10, Hebrews 4:12, Proverbs 21:2).

questions.question: According to Psalms 7:10, who does God save and defend?
questions.correctAnswer: The upright in heart
questions.explanation: God is portrayed as the defender and savior of those who are upright in heart (Psalms 7:10). This reflects the biblical theme of God’s protection of the righteous (Psalm 18:20-24, Proverbs 2:7, Matthew 5:8, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What ongoing attitude does God have toward the wicked according to Psalms 7:11?
options: God is patient with the wicked daily
God is angry with the wicked every day
questions.correctAnswer: God is angry with the wicked every day
questions.explanation: The Psalmist states that God judges the righteous and is angry with the wicked daily (Psalms 7:11), affirming God’s holiness and intolerance of sin (Nahum 1:2-3, Romans 1:18, Hebrews 10:31, Revelation 15:1).

questions.question: What does God prepare for the unrepentant wicked according to Psalms 7:12-13?
options: Instruments of death and arrows against persecutors
questions.correctAnswer: Instruments of death and arrows against persecutors
questions.explanation: These verses describe God preparing weapons and instruments of death for the wicked who do not turn from their ways (Psalms 7:12-13). This reflects divine judgment and wrath themes seen in other scriptures (Psalm 37:14-15, Isaiah 49:2, Romans 1:18, Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: How does Psalms 7:14 describe the nature of the wicked person's actions?
options: He travails with iniquity and brings forth falsehood
He repents and turns to God
questions.correctAnswer: He travails with iniquity and brings forth falsehood
questions.explanation: The wicked is described as actively laboring in sin and producing falsehood (Psalms 7:14), illustrating the biblical portrayal of sin as productive and deceitful (Genesis 4:7, Jeremiah 17:9, John 8:44, 1 John 3:8).

questions.question: What fate does Psalms 7:15 say awaits the wicked who plots evil?
options: He falls into the pit he digged
questions.correctAnswer: He falls into the pit he digged
questions.explanation: The Psalmist declares that the wicked falls into the pit he made, symbolizing self-destruction due to evil schemes (Psalms 7:15). This theme is echoed in biblical wisdom literature (Proverbs 26:27, Ecclesiastes 10:8, Matthew 26:31, Romans 11:9).

questions.question: According to Psalms 7:16, what will happen to the evil one’s mischief and violence?
options: It will come down upon his own head
questions.correctAnswer: It will come down upon his own head
questions.explanation: The mischief and violence of the wicked will return upon himself, emphasizing divine justice and the principle of sowing and reaping (Psalms 7:16). This is consistent with scriptures like Proverbs 11:31, Galatians 6:7, Psalm 94:23, and Ezekiel 18:4.

questions.question: What is the concluding response of the Psalmist in Psalms 7:17 after declaring God's righteous judgment?
options: He will praise and sing to the LORD most high
questions.correctAnswer: He will praise and sing to the LORD most high
questions.explanation: David concludes with a commitment to praise God according to His righteousness, demonstrating worship as the proper response to divine justice (Psalms 7:17). This is consistent with biblical calls to praise God for His justice (Psalm 96:13, Isaiah 25:1, Hebrews 13:15, Revelation 19:5).

questions.question: What attribute of God is most emphasized throughout Psalms 7?
questions.correctAnswer: God as Judge and Protector
questions.explanation: The Psalm consistently highlights God’s role as righteous judge and defender of the innocent (Psalms 7:6, 7:8-11). This matches the biblical theme of God’s justice and protection (Psalm 50:6, Isaiah 33:22, Romans 8:33-34, Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: How does Psalms 7 address the problem of unjust persecution in the life of the believer?
options: By encouraging believers to take revenge
By calling on God to deliver and judge justly
questions.correctAnswer: By calling on God to deliver and judge justly
questions.explanation: David asks God for deliverance from persecutors and for God’s judgment to vindicate the innocent (Psalms 7:1, 7:6-8). This reflects biblical teaching on trusting God’s justice rather than personal vengeance (Romans 12:19, 1 Peter 2:23, Psalm 37:1-6, Matthew 5:44).
